questions.text: A 50-year-old woman visits her physician for a routine check-up. Her laboratory results reveal a fasting plasma glucose level of 104 mg/dL (5.8 mmol/L) and an HbA1c level of 44 mmol/mol (6.2%). Which of the following statements about her condition is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: She is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus.

options.label: B
options.text: She meets the criteria for pre-diabetes based on her fasting plasma glucose level.

options.label: C
options.text: Her HbA1c level indicates normal glucose metabolism.

questions.correct_answer: B. She meets the criteria for pre-diabetes based on her fasting plasma glucose level.
questions.explanation:
Difference between IFG and IGT

Criteria

Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG)

Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT)

Indicates

Poor glucose regulation after fasting

Impaired insulin sensitivity or inadequate insulin production after sugar intake

Pathophysiology:

IFG suggests early insulin resistance or beta-cell dysfunction.

IGT indicates a more pronounced glucose metabolism impairment.

Criterion

Definition

Impaired Fasting Glucose (IFG)
  • Fasting plasma glucose: ≥ 6.1 mmol/L (110 mg/dL) < 7.0 mmol/L (126 mg/dL) (Option A ruled out)
  • The American Diabetes Association suggests a lower limit of ≥ 100 mg/dL (5.6 mmol/L).

Impaired Glucose Tolerance (IGT)
  • Fasting plasma glucose: < 126 mg/dL (7.0 mmol/L)
  • 2-hour glucose after 75 g oral glucose drink: 140–200 mg/dL (7.8–11.1 mmol/L).

HbA1c Criteria

(Option C ruled out)
  • NICE guidelines: 6.0% to 6.4% (42–47 mmol/mol)
  • American Diabetes Association: 5.7% to 6.4% (39–47 mmol/mol)

Management Strategy

Details

Lifestyle Modifications
  • Weight Management: Healthy weight through diet and exercise.
  • Healthy Eating: Balanced diet low in saturated fat, cholesterol, and sugars; high in fiber, fruits, and vegetables.
  • Physical Activity: At least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity aerobic exercise weekly.

Cardiovascular Risk Management
  • Aggressive management of hypertension and dyslipidemia to reduce cardiovascular risks.

Medication
  • Consider metformin to delay progression to type 2 diabetes, if necessary.

questions.text: Which of the following is most characteristic of Type 3 Diabetes (T3DM)?

options.label: A
options.text: Insulin resistance affecting the muscles and fat tissue

options.label: B
options.text: Primarily affects cognitive functions like memory due to insulin resistance in the brain

options.label: D
options.text: Treated solely through oral hypoglycemic agents

questions.correct_answer: B. Primarily affects cognitive functions like memory due to insulin resistance in the brain
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Details

Insulin Resistance in Brain

Neurons cannot effectively respond to insulin, impairing cognitive functions like memory.

Connection to AD

AD is associated with impaired insulin signalling, leading some to label it as "diabetes of the brain."

Pathophysiology

Impaired insulin signalling leads to amyloid-beta plaques, tau tangles, oxidative stress, and neuroinflammation, contributing to neurodegeneration and cognitive decline.

Treatment Approach

(Option D ruled out)

Details

Insulin Sensitizers

Medications improving insulin sensitivity could have neuroprotective effects.

Lifestyle Interventions

Diet and exercise targeting metabolic health may slow AD progression and benefit cognition.

questions.text: Which of the following is most characteristic of Latent Autoimmune Diabetes in Adulthood (LADA)?

options.label: A
options.text: Rapid β-cell destruction similar to type 1 diabetes

options.label: C
options.text: Gradual β-cell destruction and eventual insulin requirement

options.label: D
options.text: Complete management through lifestyle modifications and oral antidiabetic agents

questions.correct_answer: C. Gradual β-cell destruction and eventual insulin requirement
questions.explanation:
Characteristic

Details

Autoimmune Basis

Presence of islet autoantibodies (e.g., GAD antibodies) indicating autoimmune β-cell destruction.

Slower Progression

Gradual β-cell destruction; patients may not initially require insulin but will eventually need it.

Diagnostic Challenge

Often confused with type 2 diabetes; islet autoantibodies help in distinguishing it.

Consideration

Details

Early Identification

Timely recognition is essential for preserving β-cell function with early insulin initiation.

Treatment Strategies

Initially managed like type 2 diabetes (lifestyle changes, oral medications); insulin therapy needed later.

Monitoring and Education

Regular monitoring (glucose, HbA1c, islet autoantibodies) and patient education on self-management are crucial.

questions.text: Which of the following is required to diagnose complete remission of Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus (T2DM)?

options.label: A
options.text: HbA1c below 6.5% and fasting glucose between 100 and 124 mg/dL without treatment

options.label: B
options.text: HbA1c below 6.0% and fasting glucose below 100 mg/dL sustained without treatment

options.label: C
options.text: HbA1c below 7.0% and fasting glucose below 110 mg/dL with lifestyle modifications

options.label: D
options.text: HbA1c below 6.5% for at least six months without medication

questions.correct_answer: B. HbA1c below 6.0% and fasting glucose below 100 mg/dL sustained without treatment

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with thalassemia major presents to the clinic with increased fatigue, joint pain, and symptoms of hyperglycemia. On examination, he has a discoloration of the skin as shown. His medical history includes multiple blood transfusions over the years. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in managing his condition?

options.label: D
options.text: Schedule a follow-up for skin assessment

questions.explanation:
Feature

Details

Cause
  • Primarily linked to thalassemia major
  • Regular blood transfusions cause pancreatic iron overload, impairing insulin secretion

Symptoms
  • Typical diabetes symptoms (hyperglycemia)
  • Joint pain and fatigue
  • Skin changes less prominent in darker complexions

Diagnosis
  • Often after diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Elevated blood glucose levels and serum ferritin indicating iron overload

Management

Details

Insulin Therapy

Many patients require insulin for effective blood glucose management.

Iron Chelation Therapy

Helps reduce body iron levels, mitigating complications from iron overload.

Regular Monitoring

Continuous assessment of blood glucose and serum ferritin is crucial to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following genetic factors is most strongly associated with an increased risk of developing Type 1 Diabetes Mellitus (T1DM) in Caucasians?
questions.explanation:
Risk Factor

Details

Viral Infections

Mumps, Coxsackie B4, Rubella (in utero), Cytomegalovirus, Epstein–Barr

Chemicals/Drugs

Nitrosamines (from smoked meats), coffee, BSA (bovine serum albumin) in cow’s milk

Dietary Hypotheses
  • Hygiene hypothesis (reduced exposure to microorganisms in early childhood might increase autoimmune disease susceptibility.)
  • Low vitamin D levels

questions.text: A 23-year-old man with a family history of diabetes presents with a diagnosis of MODY confirmed by genetic testing. He exhibits stable mild hyperglycemia and has normal renal function. Which of the following subtypes of MODY is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.explanation:
Subtype

Gene Mutated

Key Features

β-cell Glucose Sensing

MODY2

GCK
  • Mutations lead to altered glucose sensing.
  • Results in mild, stable hyperglycemia.
  • High fasting glucose; normal postprandial response.
  • Rarely requires treatment; low risk of complications.

β-cell Transcriptional Regulation

MODY1 (Option A ruled out)

HNF4α
  • Involves mutations affecting β-cell function.
  • Progressive diabetes requiring treatment.

MODY3 (Option C ruled out)

HNF1α
  • Similar to MODY1 in progressive nature.
  • Responds well to sulfonylureas.

MODY5 (Option D ruled out)

HNF1β
  • Associated with renal abnormalities (e.g., cystic disease).
  • May cause genital malformations.
  • Approximately 50% develop diabetes early in life.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male with type 2 diabetes presents for a routine check-up. His medical history includes hypertension and smoking. Laboratory results show elevated LDL cholesterol levels. He is concerned about long-term complications of diabetes. Which of the following is the most important strategy to reduce his risk of macrovascular complications?
questions.correct_answer: B. Smoking cessation and statin therapy
questions.explanation:
Condition

Increased Rate in Diabetics

Cardiovascular death

1.7 times higher

Myocardial infarction

1.8 times greater

Stroke hospitalisation

1.5 times higher

Non-traumatic amputations

60% occur in diabetics

First cardiovascular event (type 1)

3 times higher in women, 2.3 times higher in men

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presents with various complications. Which of the following conditions is not classified as a microvascular complication of diabetes mellitus?

options.label: D
options.text: Retinal ischemia develops over time leading to neovascularization

questions.correct_answer: C. Development of diabetic foot ulcers
questions.explanation:
Complication

Pathophysiology and Characteristics

Management Strategies

Diabetic Retinopathy
  • Prolonged hyperglycemia causes biochemical changes that damage retinal blood vessels.
  • Thickening of the retinal capillary basement membrane occurs.
  • Increased vascular permeability causing microaneurysms.
  • Retinal ischemia develops over time, contributing to neovascularization. (Option D ruled out)
  • Inflammatory mediators and oxidative stress
  • Regular eye examination, laser therapy, and additional treatments as needed.
  • Initial screening:
    • Type I DM - 3 to 5 years after diagnosis
    • Type II DM - at the time of diagnosis
  • Screening is conducted annually, and if the results remain normal over time, it can be done once every two years.

Diabetic Nephropathy
  • Early stages: hyperfiltration
  • Later stages: sustained proteinuria, nephrotic-range proteinuria, renal failure.
  • Microalbuminuria predicts progression in type 1, less reliable in type 2.
  • Aggressive blood pressure control (ACE inhibitors or ARBs),
  • Lifestyle changes (diet, exercise),
  • Possible renal replacement therapy in later stages

Diabetic Neuropathy
  • Axonal degeneration, schwann cell thickening, demyelination.
  • Classifications include symmetrical sensory polyneuropathy, asymmetrical motor diabetic neuropathy, mononeuropathy, and autonomic neuropathy.
  • Pain management (anticonvulsants, antidepressants, topical agents) and lifestyle modifications (glycemic control, exercise) to manage symptoms and slow progression

Diabetic Foot Ulcers
  • Trauma: Minor injuries can lead to ulceration
  • Neuropathy: Loss of sensation causes unawareness of injuries.
  • Structural foot changes, increasing pressure points and callus formation.
  • Charcot neuroarthropathy: deformities in foot bones and joints.
  • Peripheral Vascular Disease: Impaired blood flow hampers wound healing and raises infection and gangrene risk. (macrovascular complication)
  • Callus Formation: Thickened skin areas can lead to necrosis beneath, resulting in ulceration.
  • Patient Education: Educate patients on daily foot inspections, proper hygiene, appropriate footwear, and prompt care for minor injuries.
  • Multidisciplinary Team Approach: Refer patients to a team including diabetes specialists, podiatrists, vascular surgeons, and orthotists for comprehensive care.
  • Debridement and Infection Control: Remove necrotic tissue and administer timely antibiotic therapy to manage infections.
  • Pressure Relief Strategies: Utilize custom insoles, orthotic footwear, total contact casts, or aircast boots to alleviate pressure on the ulcer.
  • Revascularization and Amputation: Consider angioplasty or surgery for neuro-ischemic ulcers; perform amputations if severe infection or gangrene is present.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man had an HbA1c of 6.1% during a routine check-up. He asks his physician about the best management strategy to prevent future progression of the disease. Which of the following is the most effective approach?

options.label: A
options.text: Starting medication immediately to control blood sugar levels

options.label: B
options.text: Undergoing bariatric surgery for weight loss

options.label: C
options.text: Implementing lifestyle modifications, including diet and exercise

options.label: D
options.text: Monitoring blood glucose levels without any other changes

questions.correct_answer: C. Implementing lifestyle modifications, including diet and exercise
questions.explanation:
Strategy

Key Points

Healthy Eating
  • Focus on a balanced diet, limiting total and saturated fats.
  • Moderate carbohydrate intake (≤ 50% of daily calories) with < 11% from added sugars.
  • Consider low glycemic index (GI) foods (e.g., whole grains, legumes).
  • Aim for at least five servings of fruits and vegetables daily.
  • Consult a registered dietitian for personalized advice.

Weight Management
  • Weight loss is crucial for overweight/obese individuals to improve glycemic control.
  • Calorie restriction is essential for achieving weight loss.

Regular Physical Activity
  • Engage in at least 150 minutes of moderate-intensity or 75 minutes of vigorous-intensity exercise weekly.
  • Include muscle-strengthening exercises twice a week.
  • Minimize sedentary time (>90 minutes of inactivity).
  • Seek guidance for managing exercise-related hypoglycemia, especially in individuals with type 1 diabetes.

Alcohol Moderation
  • Follow recommended alcohol intake guidelines to avoid hypoglycemia.
  • Consume alcohol with food to mitigate risks.

Smoking Cessation
  • Quit smoking to lower the risk of cardiovascular disease and other health issues.

Regular Monitoring
  • Schedule regular checkups to monitor glucose levels, blood pressure, and lipid profiles.
  • Manage cardiovascular risk factors aggressively.
  • Consider early intervention with medications like metformin if necessary.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents with increased thirst, frequent urination, and fatigue over the past few weeks. Her parents mention that she has lost weight despite having a normal appetite. On examination, she appears dehydrated and has a fruity-smelling breath. Blood tests reveal a plasma glucose level of 350 mg/dL and a positive urine ketone test. Which of the following is true for this condition?
questions.explanation:
Type of DM

Characteristics

Type 1 DM
  • Pediatric onset
  • Autoimmune destruction of >80% beta cells due to HLA association
  • Leads to insulinopenia
  • Auto-antibody: anti-ICA
  • Risk of diabetic ketoacidosis (utilizes ketone bodies for energy)

Type 2 DM
  • Relative insulin resistance
  • Increased fasting insulin levels (radioimmune insulin levels) (Option B)
  • Polygenic cause (Option C)

MODY (Maturity Onset Diabetes of the Young)
  • Monogenic form
  • Autosomal dominant inheritance pattern
  • Expressed in every generation
  • At least 2 consecutive generations with DM history
  • It resembles Type 2 diabetes but usually occurs in younger individuals.

Gestational Diabetes Mellitus (Option D)

Defined as:

1. Plasma glucose > 140 mg/dL after 75g of glucose (WHO criteria)

2. After 100g glucose (Carpenter/Coustan diagnostic criteria - ADA criteria):

  • 1 hr later, plasma glucose ≥ 180 mg/dL
  • 2 hr later, plasma glucose ≥ 155 mg/dL
  • 3 hr later, plasma glucose ≥ 140 mg/dL

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents for a routine check-up. She is overweight but has no family history of diabetes or hypertension. According to the American Diabetes Association (ADA) guidelines, what is the most appropriate screening recommendation for her?

options.label: A
options.text: No screening is necessary until age 60.

options.label: B
options.text: Screen now and re-screen every 3 years if normal.

options.label: C
options.text: Screen every year regardless of results.

options.label: D
options.text: Screen only if symptoms of diabetes appear.

questions.correct_answer: B. Screen now and re-screen every 3 years if normal.
questions.explanation:
Population

First Screening Age

Rescreening Frequency

General Adults

45 years

Every 3 years if normal

Overweight/Obese Adults

Any age

Based on individual risk factors

Individuals with Prediabetes

N/A

Annually

High-Risk Ethnic Groups

<45 years

Every 3 years if normal

Pregnant Women

During pregnancy

As needed based on risk factors

questions.text: A glucagon-stimulated C-peptide test is performed on a patient receiving exogenous insulin therapy. Which of the following findings is most likely in a patient with long-standing type 1 diabetes?

options.label: A
options.text: Elevated serum C-peptide levels after glucagon stimulation

options.label: B
options.text: Decreased or absent serum C-peptide levels

options.label: C
options.text: Normal C-peptide levels but reduced blood glucose response

options.label: D
options.text: Elevated C-peptide levels with low insulin resistance

questions.correct_answer: B. Decreased or absent serum C-peptide levels
questions.explanation:
Step

Description

Baseline sample

Draw blood to measure the initial C-peptide level.

Glucagon injection

Inject glucagon to stimulate insulin production.

Follow-up samples

Take blood samples at intervals (e.g., 30 & 60 minutes) post-injection.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with type 2 diabetes presents for a follow-up after recent medication changes. His physician wants to assess how well his blood glucose levels have been controlled over the past few weeks. Which of the following tests is the most appropriate for short-term monitoring of his glycemic control?
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference Ranges
  • ↳ Population Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L) Non-diabetic 200–285 Diabetic (poor control) Elevated above 285
  • ↳ Population Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)
  • ↳ Population
  • ↳ Population
  • ↳ Population
  • ↳ Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)
  • ↳ Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)
  • ↳ Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)
  • ↳ Non-diabetic 200–285
  • ↳ Non-diabetic
  • ↳ Non-diabetic
  • ↳ 200–285
  • ↳ 200–285
  • ↳ Diabetic (poor control) Elevated above 285
  • ↳ Diabetic (poor control)
  • ↳ Diabetic (poor control)
  • ↳ Elevated above 285
  • ↳ Elevated above 285
  • ↳ Comparison to HbA1c : HbA1c reflects glucose over 2-3 months . (Option A ruled out) Comparison to Fasting, Postprandial Plasma Glucose and OGTT: Provide only single-time-point results. (Options C & D ruled out)
  • ↳ Comparison to HbA1c : HbA1c reflects glucose over 2-3 months . (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Comparison to HbA1c
  • ↳ 2-3 months
  • ↳ (Option A ruled out)
  • ↳ Comparison to Fasting, Postprandial Plasma Glucose and OGTT: Provide only single-time-point results. (Options C & D ruled out)
  • ↳ Comparison to Fasting, Postprandial Plasma Glucose and OGTT:
  • ↳ single-time-point results.
  • ↳ (Options C & D ruled out)

Population

Fructosamine Levels (µmol/L)

Non-diabetic

200–285

Diabetic (poor control)

Elevated above 285

questions.text: A 45-year-old obese woman with no acute symptoms presents for routine screening. Given her family history of diabetes, which diagnostic test would provide the most reliable indication of her glycemic status and aid in the early detection of diabetes?

A 60-year-old male with a history of hypertension presents for a routine check-up. He has no symptoms but is concerned about his blood sugar levels. His lab results show: Fasting plasma glucose: 128 mg/dL (7.1 mmol/L) HbA1c: 6.7% What is the next best step?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat fasting plasma glucose for confirmation

options.label: B
options.text: Perform an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)

options.label: C
options.text: Start lifestyle modifications and monitor for pre-diabetes

options.label: D
options.text: Diagnose diabetes mellitus and initiate treatment

questions.correct_answer: A. Repeat fasting plasma glucose for confirmation
questions.explanation:
Test

Diagnostic Threshold for Diabetes

Random plasma glucose

≥ 200 mg/dL

Fasting plasma glucose

≥ 126 mg/dL

Oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT)

≥ 200 mg/dL after 2 hours with 75 g glucose.

OGTT is not necessary if fasting glucose is already in the diabetic range. (Option B ruled out)

Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)

< 5.7% : Normal

5.7% - 6.5% : Pre-diabetic

> 6.5% : Diabetic

Type

Blood Glucose Range

Impaired fasting glucose

110–125 mg/dL (6.1–6.9 mmol/L) (Option C ruled out)

Impaired glucose tolerance

Fasting < 126 mg/dL + 2-hour OGTT: 140–200 mg/dL (7.8–11.1 mmol/L).

Investigation

Purpose

Islet Autoantibodies

Indicates type 1 diabetes (autoimmune destruction).

C-peptide Measurement

Differentiates type 1 (low C-peptide) vs. severe insulin resistance (high C-peptide).

Urine Protein Testing

Detects microalbuminuria for nephropathy and cardiovascular risk.

Lipid Profile

Identifies dyslipidemia, a common comorbidity in diabetes.

Liver and Thyroid Tests

Detects abnormalities related to diabetes complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is most likely to cause drug-induced diabetes by impairing insulin secretion from the pancreas?
questions.explanation:
Drug Class

Mechanism

Key Note

Glucocorticoids

Increase insulin resistance (Option A ruled out)

Can cause temporary or type 2 diabetes

Thiazide diuretics

Impair insulin secretion from the pancreas (Option B)

Used to treat hypertension

Phenytoin

Possible liver-related mechanism (Option C ruled out)

Anticonvulsant medication

Drug

Effect

β-lactam antibiotics

Interfere with urine glucose tests (Option D ruled out)

Levodopa

May cause false-positive glucose results

Salicylates

Affect glucose measurements in urine

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents with complaints of progressive changes in his appearance over the past few years. He notes that his shoes no longer fit, and his wedding ring feels tight on his finger. His wife has remarked that he seems to have developed more pronounced facial features. He also reports excessive sweating and occasional headaches. On examination, there is noticeable frontal bossing. Which of the following complications is most likely associated with his condition?
questions.explanation:
Category

Causes of Diabetes

Description

Pancreatic Damage
  • Damage to the exocrine component of the pancreas
  • Cystic fibrosis: common cause

Causes diarrhea and steatorrhea due to malabsorption and DM manifestations.

Chronic pancreatitis

Insulinopenia occurs due to reduced beta cell mass.

Lack of insulin leads to elevated blood sugar

Endocrinopathies

Acromegaly

Increased growth hormone (GH) levels lead to insulin resistance.

Pheochromocytoma

Increased norepinephrine or epinephrine levels cause elevated blood sugar, palpitations, and sweating.

Cushing's Syndrome

Grossly elevated cortisol levels lead to insulin resistance and DM.

Medications

Steroids

Long-term use can induce insulin resistance.

Immunomodulators

mTOR inhibitors and calcineurin inhibitors can affect glucose metabolism

Thiazides

Hydrochlorothiazide may cause elevated HbA1c values, leading to impaired glucose tolerance.

Propranolol

It can affect glucose metabolism, and it is used for migraine prophylaxis and anxiety management.

Antipsychotics

Some antipsychotic medications can lead to weight gain and insulin resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Type 1.5 Diabetes Mellitus is incorrect?

options.label: A
options.text: Characterized by autoimmune destruction of beta cells

options.label: B
options.text: Patients are typically diagnosed in childhood

options.label: C
options.text: It is often misdiagnosed as Type 2 DM

options.label: D
options.text: C-peptide levels decline more slowly compared to Type 1 DM

questions.correct_answer: B. Patients are typically diagnosed in childhood
